options.label: A
options.text: Part of the fallopian tube that acts as a functional anatomical sphincter is the isthmus

options.label: B
options.text: The site for fertilization is amupuloisthemic junction

options.label: C
options.text: The widest part of the fallopian tube is ampula

options.label: D
options.text: The part ligated during tubectomy is ampula

questions.correct_answer: D. The part ligated during tubectomy is ampula
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The part ligated during tubectomy is ampula Permanent Method of Contraception Female Sterilization First performed in 1823 in London by Dr J Blundell. Female sterilisation is the most commonly used contraceptive method in the world Child norm for sterilzation in India: 1 child at least 1 year old Husband concert is for sterilzation atom not necessary. M/C method of post partum sterilization- Minilaparotomy M/C method of female sterilzation- Laparoscopic sterilization using falope rings Techniques It can be done laparoscopically (procedure of choice these days) or by mini laparotomy (incision <3 cms) Methods of female sterilization The basic fundamental principle in female sterilization is breaking the continuity of both fallopian tubes by removing a small segment of both tubes. Prerequisites Criteria for Eligibility (Self-declaration by the client should be the basis of this information) Patient should be Female should be below the age of 49 years and above the age of 22 years. The couple should have at least one child whose age is above one year unless the sterilization is medically indicated. Female or her partners must not have undergone sterilization in the past (not applicable in cases of failure of previous sterilization). Clients must be in a sound state of mind so as to understand the full implications of Mentally ill clients must be certified by a psychiatrist and a statement should be given by the legal guardian/spouse regarding the soundness of the client's state of mind. Site of Sterilization Sterilization is done at the junction of promixal and middle third of tube - the loop formed consists mainly of isthmus and part of ampullary region. Best chances for reversibility is seen in- Isthmo - isthmic type of anastomosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Part of the fallopian tube that acts as a functional/anatomical sphincter is the Option: B. The site for fertilization is the amupuloisthemic junction . Option: C. The widest part of the fallopian tube is ampula.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is admitted to the obstetrics and gynecology department for a scheduled tubal ligation procedure. Two days postoperatively the patient has a high fever and shows signs of hypovolemic shock. A radiographic examination reveals a large hematoma adjacent to the external iliac artery. Which of the following vessels was most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ovarian arteries The ovarian arteries arise from the abdominal aorta, descend retroperitoneally along the posterior abdominal wall, and cross just anterior to the external iliac vessels. The ovarian arteries a re the most likely source of blood from a hematoma following a tubal ligation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D: The ascending and descending uterine arteries and inferior vesical arteries branch from the internal iliac arteries and are not likely to be the source of blood in this situation.

Extraedge:

MINI-LAP VIS-A-VIS LAPAROSCOPIC STERILIZATION Mini-lap Laparoscopic sterilization 1. Cost Minimal maintenance Expensive, requires adequate maintenance. 2. Personnel Any medical personnel with surgical skill. Should only be performed by persons with special training. 3. Selection of time Any time - Puerperium, Interval, with MTP Should not be done within 6 weeks of delivery or with enlarged uterus. 4. Contraindication Practically none. Can be done in conditions contraindicated for laparoscopy. Lung lesions, organic heart diseases, intra-abdominal adhesions, extreme obesity. 5. Complication life-threatening Minimal but usually not. Minimal but at times fatal. 6. Hospital stay 3-5 days. 3-4 hours. 7. Failure rate 0.1-0.3% 0.2-0.6% 8. Reversibility Difficult due to adhesions and reduced remnant tubal length. Easier and effective. Only 4 mm of the tube is destroyed with the Filshie clip

questions.text: The following are true related with regards to vasectomy except:

options.label: C
options.text: Involves ligation and division of the spermatic cord

options.label: D
options.text: Partner (wife may be given DMPA for 3 months

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leads to immediate sterility Vasectomy consists of dividing and excising a part of the vas deferens (with spermatic cord). It leads to permanently ending the fertility of men. Failure rate 0.15%. The sterility does not occur immediately after vasectomy. Sperms remain in semen for 15–20 ejaculations which are approximately 3–4 months, during which time an additional contraceptive method (condom by male or DMPA by wife should be used).

Highyeild:

Male Sterilization Vasectomy It is a simple, safe, and effective surgical procedure There are two methods by which the vasdeferens can be approached conventional vasectomy and no-scalpel vasectomy. precaution: The sterility does not occur immediately after vasectomy. Sperms remain in semen for 15–20 ejaculations which is approximately 3–4 months, during which time an additional contraceptive method (condom by male or DMPA by wife should be used). Advantages of No-scalpel Vasectomy A smaller wound than the conventional technique Earlier resumption of sexual activity after surgery (because it requires no scrotal incision) Neither conventional nor no-scalpel vasectomy is time-consuming, but it has been reported that the vasectomy procedure time is shorter when skilled providers use the no-scalpel technique Failure Rate = 1 -0.15% Reversibility - Revarsal is possible with microsurgery (vasovasostomy) giving a 90% return of sperm and a 70% pregnancy rate Complications: Complications of NSV are significantly less. Immediate - (1) Wound sepsis which may lead to scrotal cellulitis or abscess; (2) Scrotal hematoma. Remote - (1) Frigidity or impotency-It is mostly psychological in origin. (2) Sperm granuloma is due to an inflammatory reaction to sperm leakage. This can be prevented by cauterization or fulguration of the cut ends. (3) Chronic intrascrotal pain and discomfort (post-vasectomy syndrome) may be due to scar tissue formation, or tubular distension of the epididymis. Options B, C, and D are the correct options.

questions.text: The least failure in sterilization occurs with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unipolar cauterization Unipolar cauterization by laparoscopy although has the least failure but is not done as it leads to intestinal burns and has thus been abandoned Female tubal sterilization methods-10 year cumulative failure rates: Unipolar cauterization – 0.75% Postpartum tubal excision – 0.75% Silastic ring/Falope ring – 1.77 Interval tubal exclusion – 2.01 Bipolar coagulation – 2.48 Hulka - Clemens clips – 3.65

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Silastic ring/Falope ring – 77 Option: B. Bipolar coagulation – 48 Option: D. Hulka - Clemens clips – 3.65

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is associated with the maximum chance of recanalization during surgery for the reversal of tubal ligation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isthmo-isthmic anastomosis It is important to select the site of tubal ligation carefully which should ideally be done at the tubal isthmus. This is because, in the event of the patient desiring a tubal recanalization procedure, the isthmo-isthmic anastomosis carries the best chances of success.

Highyeild:

Reversal of Tubal Ligation The most important facto r affecting successful reversal is the length of the remaining tube For reversal, the minimum length of the reconstructed tube should be 4 cm (with ampullary part 2 cms) Most suitabl e for reversal is clips followed by silastic bangs/rings , BUT most commonly used for laparoscopic tubal ligation is a silastic band followed by clips. Type of Reanastomosis : Isthmoisthmic > Isthmoampullary The least suitable for reversal is monopolar cautery followed by bipolar cautery technique. The chances of ectopic pregnancy after reversal are very high.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D: are incorrect.

questions.text: Sterilization is commonly performed at which site of the fallopian tube:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isthmus Sterilization is done at the junction of the proximal and middle third—the loop formed consists mainly of the isthmus and part of the ampullary region of the tube .Therefore, if in options isthmo ampullary is given, it is the best choice but if isthmo ampullary is not given Isthmus is the next best choice.

questions.text: A couple is advised to use barrier methods after vasectomy till:
questions.correct_answer: B. No sperms in the ejaculate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No sperms in the ejaculate Sterility does not occur immediately after Sperms remain in the semen for 15–20 ejaculation, requiring continued contraception for about 3 months. So the couple is advised to use some form of contraception for the next 3 months or 15–20 ejaculates, but this can vary from person to person. So the best is to repeat the semen analysis and confirm that the patient has become azoospermic. This is the reason why after vasectomy, 2 separate semen analysis should be done to confirm the absence of sperms in the ejaculate and then additional contraception discontinued.

Highyeild:

Male Sterilization Vasectomy It is a simple, safe, and effective surgical procedure There are two methods by which the vas deferens can be approached conventional vasectomy and no-scalpel vasectomy. Precaution: The sterility does not occur immediately after vasectomy. Sperms remain in semen for 15–20 ejaculations which is approximately 3–4 months, during which time an additional contraceptive method (condom by male or DMPA by wife should be used). Advantages of No-scalpel Vasectomy A smaller wound than the conventional technique Earlier resumption of sexual activity after surgery (because it requires no scrotal incision) Neither conventional nor no-scalpel vasectomy is time-consuming, but it has been reported that the vasectomy procedure time is shorter when skilled providers use the no-scalpel technique Failure Rate = 1 -0.15% Reversibility - Revarsal is possible with microsurgery (vasovasostomy) giving a 90% return of sperm and a 70% pregnancy rate Complications: Complications of NSV are significantly less. Immediate: (1) Wound sepsis which may lead to scrotal cellulitis or abscess. (2) Scrotal hematoma. Remote: (1) Frigidity or impotency-It is mostly psychological in origin. (2) Sperm granuloma is due to an inflammatory reaction to sperm leakage . This can be prevented by cauterization or fulguration of the cut ends. (3) Chronic intrascrotal pain and discomfort (post-vasectomy syndrome) may be due to scar tissue formation, or tubular distension of the epididymis.
